sense.name: (Cause to) come to the boiling point and change from liquid to vapor.
sense.commentary: NOTE: PATIENT must be a liquid.
sense.examples: Water boils at 100 degrees Celcius. The sauce should boil down to one cup. The chef boiled down the sauce by cooking it for a long time. I boiled the water to purify it.

sense.name: Immerse or be immersed in a boiling liquid, for purposes of cooking or processing.
sense.commentary: NOTE: PATIENT must NOT be a liquid. Compare to Sense 1.
sense.examples: The chef boiled the potatoes. Factory workers boil the wool in preparation for drying and spinning. They extracted confessions by boiling prisoners alive.

sense.name: Be agitated.
sense.commentary: NOTE: Do note use for emotional states; this sense refers only to physical agitation.
sense.examples: The sea boiled in the storm. The skies boiled with dark, swirling clouds.

sense.name: Be agitated in an emotional state.
sense.examples: The customer was boiling with anger. Anger boiled inside the customer.

sense.name: BOIL DOWN: be the essential element
sense.examples: The proposal boils down to a compromise. The whole novel boils down to an insecure, highschool fantasy.

sense.name: BOIL OVER: (cause to) overflow while boiling.
sense.commentary: NOTE: entity that boils over must either be a liquid or imply the presence of a liquid.
sense.examples: The milk is boiling over. Charles' negligence caused the rice to boil over.

sense.name: BOIL OVER: (Cause) an emotional state to become apparent or acted upon; (cause) a situation to change state or status by (emotional) will.
sense.examples: His anger boiled over and he began to beat his opponent. A long-running controversy over the publication of caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad by a Danish newspaper boiled over in the past few days.
